Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Development and manufacture of a new class of high-figure-of-merit bulk thermoelectric nanomaterials
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project seeks to enable the commercialization of a scalable bottom-up microwave synthesis process invented and demonstrated for obtaining bulk thermoelectric nanomaterials with 25% higher figure-of-merit ZT at 50% cost savings than the state of the art. We anticipate the results of the project to expand the scope of, and transform, high efficiency thermoelectric refrigeration and waste-heat harvesting technologies. In particular, this project aims to transmute our synthesis approach to a manufacturing technology that consistently yields ton-scale nanothermoelectrics with ZT>1. The objectives are to 1) Complete the design of, and implement a microwave manufacturing platform with a 10 tons/year capacity, 2) Develop protocols for industrial-scale wafer production from the nanomaterials for device fabrication, and 3) Devise methods to further increase ZT through process optimization. The knowhow generated from the demonstration of kilogram-scale production shown in Phase I provides the foundation for the Phase II effort. We will focus on the widely used bismuth and antimony tellurides, and their alloys. We will strive to maximize process flexibility to facilitate greater ZT gains through process optimization and to facilitate the adaptation of our process technology to other thermoelectric nanomaterials for refrigeration and waste-heat harvesting.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project will be to unlock and access the multi-billion dollar potential of thermoelectrics for transforming solid-state cooling. Thermoelectric materials already support a ~$1B/year industry, but has promise to be multi-fold higher if the conversion efficiency is increased just two-fold by using nanomaterials. The project will scale-up a nanomaterials manufacturing technology targeted to create new high efficiency solid-state cooling devices that can replace the current refrigeration and air-conditioning technologies based on environmentally unfriendly gases, and create high-efficiency electricity generators from waste heat, significantly expanding the thermoelectric markets and impacting global energy usage and addressing global environmental concerns. The work performed in the project will result in low-cost high-value thermoelectric nanomaterials manufacturing to replace extant energy-intensive methods that cannot cost-effectively produce high-efficiency materials. This will lead to introduction of a new class of nanomaterials with superior properties than that available currently in the marketplace. The work will expand the scope of thermoelectric device applications, paving the way for power generation technologies through implementation of our manufacturing method for other materials systems. The project is anticipated to create 10-25 jobs in 3-5 years besides making New York State a global player in thermoelectrics innovation and nanomaterials manufacturing.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Thermoelectric energy conversion has long tantalized transformative coolant-free solid-state cooling and waste-heat-to-electricity generation. Thermoelectric harvesting of just 7% of US waste-heat at only 5% efficiency presages almost 300GWh of clean-electricity every year. In addition, thermoelectric heat-pumps are solid-state, compact, environmentally-friendly, and obviate moving parts and fluid coolants. Bismuth telluride alloys are the bedrock of the global thermoelectric industry, underpinning a global billion-dollar market but simultaneously limiting applications due to low thermoelectric figures of merit, unchanged for decades. This is crucial because the efficiency of thermoelectric energy conversion is proportional to the ZT.

It is widely recognized that new materials with high ZT are needed to double extant conversion efficiencies to fully realize the transformative promise of thermoelectrics technologies e.g. ZT>2 would enable ubiquitous replacing of mechanical coolers, self-powered sensors, automotive and industrial heat-to-electricity capture of >500GWh. Realizing high ZT materials is an exacting challenge because it involves the control of three unfavorably coupled transport properties, namely, electrical conductivity, thermal conductivity, and the Seebeck coefficient. An emergent paradigm is nanostructuring, which however has historically been difficult to scale-up and recreate outside of academic laboratories into low-­cost, high­-volume production methods. 

Our technology is a scalable microwave-stimulated wet-chemical processing approach that combines nanostructuring, compositional control and parts-per-million-level impurity doping, to address this challenge. At ThermoAura Inc., we have translated this lab-scale nano-science concept to a tons-scale materials manufacturing nanotechnology for producing high-performance thermoelectrics with tunable properties.

Our NSF SBIR project sought to realize the commercialization of bulk thermoelectric nanomaterials with high ZT>1. The main focus of the project is to develop a world-class manufacturing facility for producing market-ready high ZT thermoelectric nano-products. Our efforts are focused on nanostructured n-bismuth telluride and p-antimony telluride, and their alloys, since they dominate the industry and are commercially crucial. ThermoAura Inc. developed and scaled-up the nanopowder manufacturing process technology into the NanoWave® in the project to make tons-scale nanocrystal powder, and worked on Spark-Plasma Sintering (SPS) processes to produce laboratory-scale wafers of thermoelectric alloys from nanopowder. Our main goals under the project were market introduction of, and commercializing n-type materials in the form of nanocrystalline wafer and scale-up of p-type alloy manufacturing. Our objectives were scale-up of SPS processes and developing high-volume manufacturing of nanostructured wafer and ingot products from nanopowder. The project work was first performed on laboratory tools and then production-scale nanopowders made by NanoWave® and on our automated, state-of-art production SPS press tool. Our approaches combined process engineering for solving up-scaling and manufacturing problems for wafer making, basic chemistry R&D for p-type nanopowder synthesis with analyses of complex multi-parametric data sets for optimization and materials engineering.

We have achieved several technical milestones and breakthroughs in the course of our project. 1. We scaled-up a novel wet-chemical process using microwaves, designed and built a tons-scale nanopowder production plant in Upstate NY 2. We finished the installation, commissioning and qualification of a high-volume SPS production press tool for manufacturing nanocrystalline wafers. 3. Achievement of high thermoelectric power-factor >4 mW/mK2 in n-type nanocrystalline bismuth telluride alloys - a breakthrough for a bottom-up process. 4. Upscaling nanostructured wafer and ingot production. 5. Demonstrating flexible printed thermoelectric power-generators in collaboration with an academic partner. Our major work during the project was focused on scaling nanopowder production followed by work on single-wafer fabrication on laboratory-scale tools to a high-volume mass-manufacturing process on an industrial-scale press with products ready for marketing and commercialization by the thermoelectric industry.
